Revelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Michel

texts.en:
Michel, 26, is single. He takes care of two relatives, aged 11 and 14. Michel is a self-employed businessman selling cosmetics such as body lotions and toothpaste, as well as foodstuffs such as rice, sugar, flour and cooking oil. His shop is open from 6am until 5.30pm daily.

Michel has requested a loan through Vision Finance in order to expand his shop by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice. With this large quantity, he will also start wholesaling. In doing so, he hopes to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to renovate his house, continue paying school fees for his two relatives and build a secure future.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of sugar and rice.

loans.name: Sann

texts.en: Mrs. Sann M. is a villager in Prey Sambuor village in Takeo province. She was born in 1978. She and her husband, Mr. Nem Nob, are farmers who own a piece of land to grow rice to sell to support their family living. He is a government worker too.  It is time to grow rice, but she does not have enough rice seed for growing. So to improve production, Mrs. Sann M. is seeking a loan to buy rice seed and with the rest of the loan she is going to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the garment factory, and the youngest one is four years old. Her husband appears in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is married and has two children aged 25 and 23. She plants and harvests rice and corn crops and then sells her harvest to the market. Farming has been the source of her family's income for quite some time now. She has worked hard to build her business and provide her family with a better standard of living.
Gina joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Having attained elementary education, Emma S., 42, wants to achieve more in life, not just for herself but for her family as well. Emma lives in Baseco Port Area, Manila, along with her eight children. Three of her children are already working, four are living at home and one is in elementary grade.
Emma presently owns and manages a small store of accessories, electronic items, gift items, kitchen utensils and other items commonly used in household chores in Filipino homes. Her store is situated along Corazon Aquino Public Market in Baseco, Manila. She buys her items in bulk quantities and sells them piecemeal with minimum mark-up. Emma earns at least 10,000 PHP monthly from her business, which she uses to meet her family's needs and add to her present business capital.
Emma's current challenge is that the local government keeps transferring vendors' stores, including hers, from one place to another. She hopes this month the local government will settle them in a permanent location at the market. She also hopes that her business will continue to grow and that she will be able to send all her children all the way through college. To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional items for her store. Emma believes that through this loan, she will be able to expand her inventory and increase her earning capacity.
As a CCT community partner*, Emma faithfully attends her weekly fellowship meetings where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God as a mother and as a micro-entrepreneur.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her store

loans.name: Christopher Musau

texts.en:
Christopher is 62 years old and married to Monica, who contributes to the family income. He has been practicing both dairy and crop farming for a period of 10 years, with an income of about 45,000 Kenyan shillings per month.

He is taking his first loan and intends to use it to buy seeds and fertilizer in preparation for next planting season. He hopes to be a leading farmer and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a plot of land to dig dirt for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with four children (two boys and two girls) all of whom attend school.  She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she has runs a school which contributes to her other source of livelihood.  Eunice faces a major challenge of seasonality.  During the rainy season the demand is lower compared to the sunny dry season where the demand for goods is high.  She hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the 30,000 KES loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking oil.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Isai

texts.en:
Isai is 35 years old. He is married with one child who is two years old. He is a carpenter. He makes and repairs home and office furniture (e.g. tables, chairs, beds, wardrobes, etc.).  He employs five people in his business.

He will use this loan to add to his stock of wood.  He says that once he gets this loan, he will make a profit and pay the school fees of his child and improve the welfare of the family.

loans.use: To increase his stock of wood.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and one child. He worked in restaurants for more than 15 years and in 2008 he decided to open his own restaurant. He is the only income provider for his family. He obtained his first Kiva loan and he was a very good client with prompt payments.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his inventory, his business sales, and therefore his profits. He is very positive about his future and hopes to continue the growth of his business.

loans.use: to increase his inventory

loans.name: Munyuoki

texts.en:
Munyoki K. is 34 years old and married to Ndanu . He has two children aged 5 and 4 years. He has been running his retail shop for a period of seven years with an income of about 40,000 Kenya shillings a month.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD and he intends to use it to add stock of flour, rice and sugar to his shop. He hopes to expand his business and own a wholesale shop in the future. He also dreams of buying a lory to transport his goods.

loans.use: To add flour, rice and sugar to his shop.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel J. is from the town of Banga. He is 45 years old. Joel is married. To make a living, Joel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. 

Joel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Joel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Having attained high school education, Ma. Elena E., 47, is a single mother who wants to achieve more in life, not just for herself but for her family as well. Ma. Elena lives in Baseco Port Area, Manila, along with her one healthy daughter who is currently attending preparatory school.

Ma. Elena presently owns and manages a business selling branded apparel, fashion jewelry and accessories, household items, footwear and the like.  She basically buys these items in bulk quantities and sell them piecemeal with minimum mark-up.  Her customers are her neighbors and the community. Ma. Elena earns at least Php 8,000 net income for the month.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan.  She plans to use this loan to purchase additional stock to sell and also to buy those items ordered in advance by her customers.  Ma. Elena believes that through this loan, she will be able to expand her inventory and thereby increase her earning capacity as micro-entrepreneur.

At present, Ma. Elena faces difficulty in collecting accounts from her customers. Still, she is determined not to be swayed by these struggles and aims to make her business grow. She prays that her business will continue so that she can earn more savings for her child's future.  As CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives as a mother and as a micro-entrepreneur.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Phylis

texts.en:
Phylis is a single woman with one son who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent bills. 

She has operated M-pesa (mobile banking services) for the past year, operating wholesale and retail. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. Phylis faces a major challenge of theft in her business. She hopes to become a Safaricom dealer in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a cash float for mobile banking services( M-pesa) and scratch cards for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her business.

loans.use: To purchase a cash float for mobile banking services ( M-pesa) and scratch cards for sale

loans.name: Venus' Group

texts.en:
Venus lives in Mian Channu which is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She married I. M. 23 years ago. Since then she has been living in a 2-room brick house in  Mian Channu. Her husband is involved in an animal sales business. He raises animals (goats), and then sells them to his customers. He has been in this line of work for the past 10 years and now manages to have a good number of customers. 

Venus has given birth to three sons and two daughters. Her two younger children are getting their education while her elder ones left their education after completing their matriculation. Now her eldest son works as a salesman in a soap manufacturing company. Her elder daughter is a nurse while the 2nd one does sewing for neighborhood clients. 

Venus has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase some goats to sell at a profit. Venus is very hopeful about the positive growth of her husband’s business and about the better financial future of her family. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes it will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: To buy goats for resale

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoeun D. lives in Svay Khang Cheung village in Takeo province.   She is 30-year-old and is married with two children. Her older child is enrolled in a local public school and the younger one is 4-year-old. 

Mrs. Hoeun D. is a rice wine maker and pig breeder.  She is able to earn a small income to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Sok Leng Sor, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. 

In the rice field, Mrs. Hoeun D. has problem because the field has infertile soil, is located far away from the irrigation system, and has a lot of insects.  To improve rice production, Mrs. Hoeun D. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rice seed.  With the rest of the loan she will buy pig food. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, rice seed, and pig feed

loans.name: Ma. Arlene

texts.en:
Ma. Arlene, 42 years old, is from the town of Banga. To make a living, Ma. Arlene raises crops, primarily rice and corn, for sale. She works hard to grow her business.

Ma. Arlene joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living business and situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ma. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia D., 47, is a woman with one simple dream in life. She does not even have a high school background, but that does not imply that her dream is not big. She is married to Jerlito, a vendor, and together they are raising four children in their home in Binondo, Manila.

Letecia runs her own sari-sari (variety) store, along with a water refilling station and the daily operation of a passenger motorcycle. All three are profitable and altogether yield earnings of about PHP 11,000 per month. Letecia focuses her attention on her variety store, which is situated at their home. Having been in business for around five years now, Letecia already knows the needs of her community and responds to them by filling her store with essential food items and other products. 

To further help her grow her business, Letecia has applied for a PHP 12,000 loan. She intends to use this loan to add more products to the array of items in her store to cater to the changing needs of her customers. Also, part of the money will be invested in her water refilling station. 

Letecia admits that competition in the area gives her a headache, but she is determined not to lose hope but to remain strong and overcome the challenge. She looks forward to earning more than enough in order to be able to have her own commercial space. She dreams of having her own house and lot,  where she can enjoy the evening rest with her family. One simple dream, but never a small dream.

As a CCT community partner, she is faithfully attending weekly fellowship* meetings where she can draw strength and inspiration as a mother, a wife, and as a micro entrepreneur.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for the variety store

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn K. is a married woman with two children – one is enrolled in a local public school and the other is too young to work or study. She and her family live in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Saret Sorn, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow rice to sell to support their family.  Mrs. Phorn K. is also employed in a garment factory. 

In the rice field, the couple has problems because their field has infertile soil, is located far away from an irrigation system, and has a lot of insects.  To improve their rice production, Mrs. Phorn K. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Agriphine

texts.en:
Agriphine C. is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees. 

She has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years, neighbors and passersby are her potential customers. Agriphine faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to own a well furnished beauty salon in the future. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase cosmetics and hair braids for her beauty salon. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and hair braids for her beauty salon

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Mrs. Pol L. is a villager in Snuol Khpos village in Takeo province.  She is a 40-year-old widow with two children – one is attending a local public school and the younger one is 4 years old. 

Mrs. Pol L. is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.   She is also a weaver. Since her weaving business is going well, she needs to expand.  To achieve this purpose, Mrs. Pol L. is requesting a loan to buy more silk.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Kabaranga Development Group-Kihihi

texts.en:
47-year-old K. Godfrey is a happily married father of 8.   For the last 5 years, he been engaged in cultivating and selling agro produce, primarily coffee, as a source of livelihood. The enterprising and diligent Godfrey says that previously he was more involved in a business selling local brews, which he still operates though it is now only secondary. Monthly, this business generates for Godfrey 300,000 shillings. 

With this loan,Godfrey says he is going to buy more bags of coffee to resell.   K. belongs to Kabaranga Development group Kihihi.

loans.use: The purchase coffee to resell

loans.name: Ushuuda Group

texts.fr: Mishonya L.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Ushuuda, âgée de 60 ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants.  Son conjoint est un chargé de crédit dans une coopérative de la place. Elle fait le petit commerce de divers (riz, plastics, souliers, etc.) au marché sectoriel de Katindo II.  Aussitôt fait le mariage, environs 35 ans, elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Vers 2008, elle bénéficia de premier  crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produits (1 sac de riz, dizaines des plastics, 10 paires souliers, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne construire confortablement une maison pour ses jeunes enfants et les  faire scolariser. La cliente Mishonya L.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Ushuuda est constitué de 34 membres.
texts.en: Mishonya L. is an entrepreneur, the president of the Ushuuda group, 60 years old, and the mother of 5 children.  Her spouse is a loan officer in a local cooperative.  She runs a small business selling diverse items (rice, plastics, shoes, etc.) at the sectoral market of Katindo II.  As soon as she was married, about 35 years ago, she began her business with her own funds, received from her husband.  Around 2008, she received her first loan of $50 from the IMF Hekima.  This new loan should allow her to stock up on new products (1 bag of rice, dozens of plastics, 10 pairs of shoes, etc.).  Moreover, her ambition is to comfortably build a house for her young children and have them educated.  The client, Mishonya L., thanks Hekima for its actions in favor of the poor, who are excluded from classic banks.  The group Ushuuda is made up of 34 members.

loans.use: 1 bag of rice, a dozen plastics, 10 pairs of shoes, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Having attained elementary education, Merlinda M., 44, wants to achieve more in life, not just for herself but for her family as well. Merlinda lives in Baseco Port Area, Manila, with her husband, Rosendo M., who is a construction worker. They have two children, both of whom are in elementary grades now.

Merlinda has been in the direct sales business for a few years. She offers branded apparel, cosmetics, footwear, accessories, etc. She buys these items at a discounted price and in bulk quantities and sells them to customers at the regular prices indicated in their product catalogs. Usually she earns at least 25% of the price in the catalog. Her customers are her neighbors, friends, relatives and the community.  Merlinda earns at least PHP 5,000 monthly.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting for a PHP 10,000 loan. She plans to use this loan to purchase items ordered in advance by her customers. Also she plans to purchase items that are usually ordered by her customers to immediately cater their orders. She believes that through this loan, she will be able to expand her inventory and increase her earning capacity.

She hopes that her business will continue to grow, generate more savings and help her to send her children all the way through college. She and her husband are also planning to build and manage their own bakery some day.  

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock to sell and also to pay for items ordered in advance by her customers

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem lives in Mian Channu, a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She came here nine years ago. Since then she has been living in a two-room brick house in an area called Amrat Nagar.
 
She is 35 years old, married to B. M., who is involved in a timber-selling business. Since gas is not available, her husband is helping people by selling timber to them. His business is working well for him as he sells a good quantity of timber every month.
 
Naseem herself is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and fulfill her household responsibilities. She makes the utmost effort to give comfort to her family by taking care of their food and clothing and so forth. She has two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is studying in fifth class while her second son is in third class. Her daughter is 8 years old and studying in class two.
  
Naseem has applied for her first loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy timber in bulk to sell to his clients. The bulk purchasing will help him fulfill the urgent need of his customers and make an extra income.
 
Naseem hopes that after the loan investment her husband’s business will be in a more profitable position.

loans.use: To buy timber for selling

loans.name: Mitchie

texts.en:
Mitchie A. is from the town of Banga. She is 34 years old. Mitchie is married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is 15 years old and the youngest is 7. To make a living, Mitchie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. 

Mitchie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mitchie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Mitchie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro, 66 years old, is from the town of Banga. He is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Pedro owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Pedro still works hard to be able to provide for his family.

Pedro joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Pedro is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Hour

texts.en:
Hour S., 62, is married and resides with her four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1.18 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 17 on the other necessary expenses. 

Hour S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase rice to plant and sell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy rice to resell

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat T., 56, is married and resides with her four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Khat T. sells traditional baskets, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 88 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. 

Khat T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase sewing machines to run a new business as a tailor. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner. Khat T. appears in the photograph with her son.

loans.use: To buy sewing machines to start a new business

loans.name: Roseminda

texts.en:
52-year-old Roseminda is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 children. She plants and harvests rice crops for a living. She also has a small pineapple farm. She sells her harvest to the market. Aside from that, she also raises ducks and turkeys. Roseminda works hard to provide her family better living conditions.

Roseminda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roseminda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Roseminda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Pong

texts.en: Pong M., 29, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. M. sells groceries, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 79 on food and USD 18 on the other necessary expenses. M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Chorn P., 47, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. P. sells groceries, earning an income of USD 10 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Aleja

texts.en:
They say a big family is a happy family. But it can be a big responsibility, too, especially if you are going to run that big family alone. This is the experience of Aleja F., 46, one of CCT*'s Community Partners in Manila. She is a widow with seven dependents. They used to live in Samar, Visayas few years back, but at present she and her family reside in Tondo, Manila.

Aleja's business is the buying and selling of plastic wares, through which she earns an average earning of Php11, 000 a month. She has done this kind of business for around two years by now. She conducts her daily business at home, with the help of a hired vendor.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting for a Php12,000 loan. She will use this fund to level up her plastic ware business, purchasing more products as she looks for more regular customers. With this, she will also have enough to pay the vendor she hires to sell her products. Indeed, this loan is one big step to help Aleja augment her family's daily needs, as it sustains her business.

Aleja says that the availability of a sales assistant is one major problem in her business. Sometimes, she finds no one available to work for her, which should not happen in any case. Nevertheless, she has big hopes that this problem will be met with a solution. Aleja hopes to save up and own a commercial space for her business. And the biggest dream of all, to see all of her children finish their schooling, because her family, big as it is, is all her heart could contain.
	

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Purchase of plastic wares for sale

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Sang A., 42, is married and resides with her six children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. A. is a housewife while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 35 on other necessary expenses. A. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income for repairing her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen belongs to Mian channu, a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, and known for its agriculture industry. She lives in a two-room brick house with her family in the area of Amrat Nagar. She is 49 years old and married to J. M.. They have two children: a son and a daughter. Her son has a business of selling construction supplies while her daughter, 10, is studying in class 4.
  
Her husband has a business of selling timbers. He operates this business in the market where he fulfills the orders of his customers. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years. 

Perveen is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy timber in bulk to serve more customers and fulfill larger orders on time. She is hopeful that this loan will be productive for her husband and will earn him better profits in the future.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In the previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and has never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy timber for selling

loans.name: James Murage

texts.en:
James Murage is 31 years old.  He is married to Hellen, who helps in his restaurant business and also does subsiststance farming. He has one child. He has been running his restaurant for a period of two years, earning an income of about KES. 6,500 per month.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD.  He intends to use it to pay rent for the restaurant space, which he pays annually. He hopes to buy a plot of land for development and give his son a quality education.

loans.use: To pay rent for restaurant

loans.name: Umi

texts.en:
Umi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a handbags selling business for the past five years, selling the handbags retail and from door to door. She also operates real estate agency houses which contributes to her other source of income. Umi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During holiday season the demand for handbags is higher than during the month of January to August where the demand is low. She hopes to become a wholesale supplier in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase stock of handbags for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her family living standards.

loans.use: To purchase stock of handbags for resale.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam Y., 29, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Y. sells vegetables, earning an income of USD 6.6 per day. Her husband transports fresh water to sell, earning an income of USD 1.6 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD $77 on food and USD $20 on the other necessary expenses. Y. is requesting a loan of USD $800 to purchase gasoline and fertilizer to improve the farming products. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy gasoline and fertilizer to improve the farming products

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and four school-aged children. He started working in the car mechanic field 20 years ago.  He represents the only income provider for the family and hopes to increase his family’s income. He has obtained 3 Kiva loans and he has been an excellent client.

He repairs different types of cars. Due to his long experience in this field, he has been able to build a good business reputation. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to improve his business by completing his set-up with the needed tools and machinery.

loans.use: to improve his business

loans.name: Phou

texts.en: Phou C., 58, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. C. sells fresh water, earning an income of USD $1.6 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD $60 on food and USD $50 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase groceries to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Nang

texts.en: Nang C., 28, is married and resides with her two children in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for rice products. C. is a farmer and a tailor, earning an income of USD $4.26 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD $2.93 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD $50 on food and USD $25 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD $1200 to purchase fertilizer and chickens to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and chickens to raise for sale

loans.name: You

texts.en: You P., 53, is married and resides with his four children in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for rice products. P. grows vegetables, earning an income of USD $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD $50 on food and USD $75 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD $1000 to purchase fertilizer and vegetable seeds to improve the current farming business. In the future, he would like to use the additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and vegetable seeds to improve the farming business

loans.name: Maurine

texts.en:
Maurine is married with two children. One of her children attends school, while the other is still too young. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water and her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

For the past three months, Maurine has operated a business selling clothes. She goes door to door selling clothing to her neighbors. Maurine’s major business challenge is the high cost of transportation. Maurine decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES to purchase a bundle of clothing and handbags to resell. In the future, Maurine hopes to open a shop.

loans.use: to purchase a bundle of clothes and handbags

loans.name: Imelda Yadao's Group

texts.en:
Imelda Y. is 49 years old and the leader of “Imelda Y.’s Group” a 10-member loan group from ASKI. She is from the village of Simmimbaan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Imelda is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. 

Imelda joined ASKI in 2006 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay tuition fees of for her child.


About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and provide

loans.name: The Sakina Siddiq Group

texts.en:
Sakina is 55 years old and has three sons. Her oldest son sells wheat and rice, and the middle child runs a vegetable-selling business. She was not able to provide for the education of her two eldest children, but her youngest son is in school and Sakina wants him to complete his education and become successful. Sakina lives with her family in Mian Channu, a small city located in Punjab Pakistan that is known for its agricultural industry. She moved there six years ago and owns a two-room brick house in the area of Amrat Nagar. Sakina is a housewife and she prefers to stay at home and run the household. Her husband is S., who also runs a business selling vegetables.

Sakina is requesting a loan from the Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s business. With the loan, he will buy a new cart as his old cart has become rough and rotten. He travels to different areas of the community to sell vegetables to customers and earn income to help the family. Sakina is a regular client of Asasah and this will be her second loan. She has established a good credit history during the past year and never misses a group meeting.

loans.use: to buy a cart and seasonal vegetables

loans.name: Badarch

texts.en:
Badarch is 63 years old and lives with her husband, two children, and a grandchild in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. With her eldest daughter’s help, Badarch operates a retail clothing business out of a stall at the local market. Her youngest daughter currently attends university and her granddaughter attends a local primary school. Her husband is a herder and raises livestock in the countryside. 

Badarch started her business in 2003 with 800,000 MNT in capital. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,200,000 MNT. Badarch’s daughter is responsible for purchasing the products that they sell in their stall and they have started to sell Oriflame cosmetic products to supplement their earnings. 

Badarch is a talkative and hardworking person. She is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes for her business. In the future, she plans to pass her business to her daughter and retire.

loans.use: to purchase clothes

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water and her greatest monthly expenses are rent and school fees.

For the past three years, Pamela has operated a business selling clothes. She sells retail, going from door to door. Pamela's major business challenge is seasonality. During the rainy winter season, demand for women’s dresses is low in comparison with the hot summer season when demand is very high. 

Pamela decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 KES to purchase a bundle of clothing and women’s dresses to sell. In the future, Pamela hopes to own a retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase a bundle clothing and women's dresses

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M. is 47 years old and lives in Parola, Binondo, Manila with her husband, Eduard Merced, who is also her business partner. They have four children who help them to run their restaurant business. Yolanda has a high school education and wants to achieve more in life, not just for herself but for her family as well. 

For the past 20 years, Yolanda has been operating the family restaurant business. Family members make up the restaurant staff. The restaurant is strategically located at the populated area of Gate 54 Area C, Parola, Binondo, Manila. They have a large menu and serve all types of meals and snacks, including barbecue, smoked fish, and grilled meat and fish. At the end of the day, the family earns at least 1,000 PHP income.

Yolanda is requesting a loan of 31,000 PHP to help to continue her business. She will use the loan to purchase needed items to improve the restaurant and to provide working capital to increase profit and savings. Yolanda admits that cost increases to purchase raw ingredients have affected her business as well as difficulties providing good service to avoid complaints from her customers and patrons. Still, Yolanda is determined not to be swayed by these struggles and aims to make her business grow.  She prays that she will be able to sustain her business and make it flourish so she can leave it as a legacy to her children.

Yolanda wishes a good, healthy and peaceful life for her family and prays that their house will be renovated before the end of this first quarter.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends weekly fellowship* meetings where she draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God and her life as a mother, a wife, and as a community partner.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase restaurant items and provide working capital

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta, 46 years old, is a married woman from the town of Banga. She is engaged in farming. She particularly plants and harvests rice crops. She rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. Violeta works hard to support her family financially.

Violeta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Violeta has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Violeta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Enhtaivan

texts.en:
Enhtaivan is 57 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her youngest son attends a local high school while her husband is a herder and raises their own livestock. 

Enhtaivan supports the entire family by operating a clothing-making business. She began her business in 2002 and has since gained a lot of experience as a seamstress. Because of her beautiful designs and the quality craftsmanship of the clothes, she has a large, loyal customer base. She produces a variety of traditional Mongolian clothing items according to her customers' orders. 

Enhtaivan is hard-working and good at her needlework. She says, “My happiest moments are when I see my customers' satisfaction while wearing clothes that I made." She is requesting a 250,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of fabrics, materials, and tools used in making a variety of traditional coats called 'deel' that are commonly used by Mongolians during Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian New Year.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of fabrics, materials, and tools

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Rather than dwelling in the past, CCT* Community Partner Lorna D. L., 45, has decided to prepare for the future. She was not able to make it to high school, but she stamped it on her mind that not graduating from a college is only a small part of her history. Lorna is married to Ibarra, a store owner. They live in Tondo, Manila, where they are raising their only child, who is now in elementary school.

Lorna co-runs a residential sari-sari (variety) store with Ibarra. Here, they buy sacks of rice and sugar and sell it retail. The rice is sold per kilo, while the sugar is repacked into pouches of usually a half kilo each. Lorna has been in business for twenty years, and they run their present sari-sari store without hiring any employees. Monthly they earn around Php 9,000.

Because she believes that her business has a future, she decided to borrow Php 14,000 to help her grow her business. She will use this loan money to purchase more sacks of rice and sugar. Lorna will make sure that her products are always available for her customers. Also, part of the loan money will go for the schooling of her child.

Lorna mentions having difficulties with customers who incur debts and with competitors in the area. However, she sees the future positively, when these difficulties are met with corresponding solutions. She dreams of a flourishing business, and a child of her own who will be finishing college with flying colors.

	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: purchase of sacks of rice and sugar

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr: Masika M. E.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Confiance, âgée de 42 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants.  Son conjoint est entrepreneur d’une officine pharmaceutique. La cliente Masika M. E.  est artiste, elle tisse les chapeaux dames en files à son domicile et les vendre au marché central de Virunga.  Environs 4 ans, qu’elle exerce cette activité d’art.  Elle bénéficia de premier  crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ vers janvier 2010. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des matériels de confection (files raphia, dentelles, tissus, etc.) et d’augmenter sa part du marché.  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son activité. La cliente Masika M. E.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe confiance est constitué de 35 membres.
texts.en: Masika M. E. is an entrepreneur, the president of the Confiance group, 42 years old, married and the mother of 8 children.  Her spouse is a businessman in a pharmacy dispensary.  The client, Masika M. E., is an artist.  She weaves women's hats from threads at her home and sells them at the central market of Virunga.  It has been about four years that she has run this art business.  She benefited from her first loan of $50 from the IMF Hekima in January 2010.  This new credit should allow her to restock on clothing materials (raffia threads, laces, cloths, etc.) and to increase her share of the market.  Moreover, her ambition is to grow her business.  The client Masika M. E. thanks Hekima for its actions in favor of the poor, who are excluded from classic banks.  She group Confiance is made up of 35 members.

loans.use: raffia threads, laces, cloths, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mangal

texts.en:
Mangal, 40 years old, lives with her husband and three daughters in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. Her husband operates a billiard service in the local market. Mangal operates an imported consumer goods and clothing items trading business out of a rented stall at a local market. 

She started her business in 2002 with a working capital of 500,000 MNT. She has gained much selling experience and knowledge of her trade over the years and attributes her success to her good accounting skills. After years of operation, she managed to expand her business by selling her merchandise out of two different spots. Today, her working capital exceeds 6,000,000 MNT. 

For the future, she hopes to grow her business and continue run her consumer goods trading business with stable operation. Mangal is a hard-working woman and says, "All I want is to provide a higher education for all three of our children. " She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to import more products from Erlian, a border city in China.

loans.use: To import more merchandise

loans.name: Kashenyi Twetungure Group A-Kihihi

texts.en:
44-year-old K. Fausta belongs to Kashenyi Twetungure group-Kihihi.  She has been operating a retail business in Nshanyi-Kihihi for 5 years. Farming was her prior business activity. By her own account, it was a worthwhile business because she was able to use the  savings from it to begin her retail business. 

Weekly, this business generates for her 100,000 shillings.  For this happily married mother of 7, the future prospects do not look bad. Her prognosis is  based on the fact that she is also going to get this loan to help her revamp her business. Fausta also ekes out additional profits from a goat selling  business. 

With this loan, Fausta says she is going to purchase more retail commodities to resell.  She says this will bring her more sales revenue.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail commodities to resell

loans.name: Karomat

texts.ru: Ибодов Каромат проживает в районе Вахдат. Ему 72 года. Женат. Имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Каромат при доме имеет земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу и выращивает овощи. Кроме того она занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. У него богатый опыт в этой сфере. В продвижении деятельности ему помогают дети. Кредит берет для закупа скота и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Karomat I. lives in the Vahdat Region. He is 72 years old. Married, with three children. His wife is a homemaker. Karomat has a land plot by his house and grows wheat and vegetables. In addition, [he]  breeds and raises livestock. He has a lot of experience with this work. His children help him with his business. He is taking out a loan in order to buy livestock and mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: Purchasing livestock and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old widow. She is from Lebanon. She lives with her 3 young children some of whom are attending school. After her husband’s death she had to work hard each day to handle her family’s expenses. In 2008, she opened a small clothing store and started to offer her customers a limited variety of clothes. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand her business operation and purchase more merchandise so she can serve her customers better. She is very optimistic about her future and intent on providing her family better living conditions.

loans.use: to expand her business operation and purchase more products

loans.name: Nasira's Group

texts.en:
Nasira lives in Mian Channu, a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has lived there with her family in a 3-room brick house for over 20 years. She has given birth to two sons. Both work in private firms for a reasonable income. They couldn’t find better jobs because of poor education which they couldn’t complete due to financial constraints. 

Nasira is a widow. Her husband died of a heart attack. It was a tragic time for her but she never gave up and faced the situation bravely. She started sewing work at her home.  Earlier, she received orders from her relatives but later on she started getting orders from her neighbors as well. She is good at her work and each of her customers acknowledges that. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her clothes-sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine which will help her complete orders in a shorter period of time and make more income every month. 
 
Nasira is hopeful that an investment will bring more profit for her and she will be able to marry off her elder son in the near future by saving money from her profit. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for sewing business

loans.name: Shamsullo

texts.ru: Гайбулоев Шамсулло житель Вахдатского района. Ему 59 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Шамсулло имеет высшее образование, педагог. По профессии работает уже 25 лет. Кроме того в свободное от работы время он занимается животноводством. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Shamsullo G. lives in the Vahdat Region. He is 59 years old. Married, with four children. His wife is a homemaker. Shamsullo has a college degree; he is a teacher. He has been working in his profession for 25 years. In addition, in his spare time he raises livestock. He mostly fattens cattle for resale. He has been doing this work for over 10 years. He is taking out a loan in order to purchase cattle.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to complete the necessities for his business and family

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 40-year-old married man and the father of 4 school-aged children. He is from Lebanon. He works as a freelance construction agent depending on customer’s demand. He has been involved in this field for twenty years. He is the only financial support for his family. He has obtained his first Kiva loan and he was a very good client with payments made on time.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional equipment and tools to improve his business and provide his customers with better service.

loans.use: purchase additional tools to improve his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand her husband's business and buy some essential tools

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget K. lives in the Nakulabye Kiyaye neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members, including her father and two sisters. For the last 10 years, she has made a living running a beauty salon. She works seven days a week, both at the salon and by selling beauty products out of her home. She has applied for a loan for 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy cosmetics, creams and hair weaves. Bridget lives in a home that she rents, and has access to electricity and piped-in water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics, creams and hair weaves

loans.name: Harrison

texts.en: Harrison is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. He lives in a house that he rents which has electricity but not piped-in water. His greatest monthly expenses are school fees and rent. He makes a living by running a retail delivery business, distributing goods from door to door using his bicycle. He sells his services to neighbors and passersby, but faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation. He hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future, but for now is applying for a loan for Kshs 20,000 to buy two bicycles to use to distribute goods. He joined Yehu to access loans that can improve his living standard.

loans.use: To buy two bicycles to use for distributing goods.

loans.name: Riffat's Group

texts.en:
Riffat lives in Mian Channu, a small city located in the Punjab, Pakistan and known for farming. She has lived in a two-room brick house with her family for the last 20 years. She is 42 years old, married to M. S. and has five children. Four of them study in different classes while oldest helps his father, who runs a business making school bags for students. Her husband’s shop is located in the market where he operates his business. He has been in this line of work for more than 10 years and has vast experience in his field of work. 

Riffat will use her portion of this group loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband's business. He will use it to buy leather, thread and zippers in bulk, which will help him complete orders on time and earn more income. This is Riffat's second loan from Asasah; in her previous loan, she proved herself to be a responsible client by paying all of her installments on time.

loans.use: To buy leather, thread and zippers for a business making school bags for students.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and four young children who are attending school. He has worked as a freelance electrician for 30 years, depending on customer’s requests. He is the only income source for the family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to pay his daughter's university fees to avoid financial problems with the university’s management and let his daughter pursue her education contentedly.

loans.use: To pay his daughter's university fees

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new carpet-weaving frame and other items for a small carpet-making business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane K. lives in the Lugala neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has five children, all of whom are in school.  For the last 10 years, she has made a living selling charcoal seven days a week. She supplements her income by selling smoked fish. Jane is applying for a loan of 100,0000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more charcoal to sell to her customers. Her main problems are transportation, especially during the rainy season, and customers who fail to make payments on time.  Her goals are to become a wholesaler, and to educate her children through the university level. Jane lives in a home that she owns, and has access to electricity and piped-in water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and electricity bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Because God is a God of chances, we ought to give other people chances to make right the mistakes they have done. Estella R., 33, lives to prove that, indeed, people deserve second chances. Estella is married to Jaime and together they raise a relatively young, big family of five children, of which one is adopted. One child is not yet of school age; two are enrolled in day care; and the other two are in elementary school.

Estella's involvement in CCT* as a Community Partner enables her to run a two-year business in direct-selling. She sells products from the clothing brand MSE Apparel to friends, neighbors, and business connections. She has no commercial space yet, and thus works at home. Estella has also begun a food stall at home, where she prepares breakfast for neighbors who are in too much of a hurry to prepare one. With these businesses, she earns around 18,000 PHP monthly.

Making room for failures while achieving the best that she can, Estella is determined to make this food stall work. To help her grow her business, she applied for a 10,000 PHP loan. She will use these funds to buy can't-do-without items like plates, spoons and forks, a kettle, and most importantly, a gas stove. While preparing for this, she also plans to boost her direct selling business by purchasing more MSE products like shirts, shoes, and pants to sell.

Estella admits struggling with the collection of payments from her customers. She mentions some have escaped the collection of payments. Also, she sees that there are times when her products would not sell. Nevertheless, Estella chooses to perceive these as second chances for her and for her customers to do better the next time. She aims to maintain a good savings account in CCT and grow her businesses so she will be able to make improvements on their house. Above all, she hopes that her children, young as they are, will not take chances, but will give it their best shot when it comes to their studies.

	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase utensils and facilities for cooking

loans.name: Buchaguzi

texts.fr: Buchaguzi N.  est entrepreneur, membre de groupe d’affaire Tenez-bon, âgée de 37 ans, veuve, mère de 4 enfants.  Son mari fut décédé suite à une maladie inopinée. Elle est vendeuse de viande de porc au marché communal  Kibabi.  Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Vers 2004, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ dans une banque communautaire. Actuellement elle  appartient au groupe solidaire ayant fait preuve des performances dans les affaires. Elle s’est déjà payée 2 parcelles bien construites. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des  15 cochons à abattre pour revendre.  En plus, elle ambitionne construire confortablement une maison à matériaux durables.  La cliente Buchaguzi N.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.
texts.en: Buchaguzi N. is an entrepreneur and a member of a business group called Tenez-bon (Keep Holding On). She is 37, a widow, and a mother of 4. Her husband died from a sudden illness. She sells pork at the Kibabi communal market. She started her business with her own funds, which she received from her late husband. Around 2004, she was granted a $50 credit from Hekima, an MFI, in a "Community Bank" (a group of 30 to 45 women who can borrow up to $1000). She has now graduated to a "Solidary Group" (made up of fewer women who can borrow bigger sums) which has been doing well in business. She has already bought 2 well-built plots. This new loan will be used to buy 15 pigs to be slaughtered and sold. She also aims to build a comfortable house from hardy materials. As a client of Hekima, Buchaguzi N. would like to thank the microfinance institution for what it does to help those who are denied access to traditional banks.

loans.use: Buying 15 pigs

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man living with his parents and two siblings. He is from Lebanon. He started his career at a young age working in a barber shop for eight years. This young man was able to open his own barber shop in 2007. He cooperates with his parents in the family’s income. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to renew his shop by placing new bricks and doing needed painting to attract more customers and serve them in an appropriate place.

loans.use: To place new bricks and do needed painting

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. Teopista has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days a week. Teopista sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail. Teopista has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through selling bananas. The main business challenges for Teopista include rainy season, transportation and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling as a wholesale-only agent and also educating her children up to university. Teopista lives in a home that she owns. She doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and electricity bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida got married 21 years ago. Since then, she has been living in a small city called Mian Channu with her husband and 6 children. Mian Channu is a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. Among her 6 children, 5 of them are boys and one is a daughter. Her 2 eldest sons work in a private organization for a low income. The other boys are getting their education. Her daughter is only a year old. 

Shahida's husband’s name is T. A. and he is a salesman by profession. He delivers food items such as chips, biscuits and candies to different groceries and general stores. First he takes orders by visiting them in the market, then delivers the orders to earn profits. 

Shahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy food items in bulk which will help him fulfill the orders on time and make larger profits. Shahida is hopeful that a loan investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and it will  help her family to survive financially. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. With her previous loan, she has proved herself a responsible client by paying her installments on time.

loans.use: To buy food items (chips, biscuits and candies) to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction supplies to repair his house

loans.name: Ann Marie

texts.en:
Life is full of challenges, but Ann Marie A., 36, is not giving in to any of them. Having finished only high school, Ann knows that being a successful entrepreneur is a challenge she also has to take, and overcome. It is good that being a Community Partner in CCT* will help her do so. Ann is married to Raul, a maintenance worker in Honda Cars Makati. They currently live in Binondo with their three children, 2 of whom are still in elementary school.

Ann is a rice retailer. Aside from that, she also sells eggs and charcoal. She would buy these items and sell them at a price her neighbors can afford. For two years, she has operated from home with the help of hired vendors. She earns around 10,000 PHP a month.

To further help her grow her business, Ann decided to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan. She intends to use this money to buy sacks of rice, as well as to replenish her charcoal supply in order to level up her business. She believes that a well-supplied store is a way towards profitability.

One specific business challenge Ann faces is the number of customers who take a long time to pay their debts, making it hard for her to replenish store supplies and buy other needed store materials. Aside from hoping to overcome this challenge, Ann also looks forward to a growing business in the next months. With full excitement, she dreams of seeing her children graduate from college.

	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase rice and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Kashenyi Twetungure Group B-Kihihi

texts.en:
42-year-old N. Edward has been in the retail business for the past 6 years in Nsanyi-Kihihi. The reason he says he started this business is because he saw a ready market for many of the retail commodities he has been trading. Weekly, this happily married father of 6 says this business generates for him 80,000 shillings. 

Edward belongs to Kashenyi Twetungure group-Kihihi. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase more retail commodities to resell.

loans.use: To buy retail commodities to resell

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty K. lives in the Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is divorced and has 1 child, who attends school. Retsy also takes care of additional family members (sister and brother) and works 6 days out of every week. Resty sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail. She also generates additional income through selling pay phone air time and a telephone booth.

Resty has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more newspaper. The main business challenges for Resty include rainy season and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a newspaper agent and also educating her children up to university. Resty lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity, but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and electricity bills.

loans.use: To buy more newspapers

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman with one boy who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

She has operated a poultry business for the past three years, selling at wholesale and at the market to food vendors and neighbours. In addition she also operates a fruit-selling business which contributes another source of income. Pauline faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to open a juice parlor in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan Shilling loan she wants to purchase a brood of chickens and repair her food sales stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a brood of chickens and repair her market stall.

loans.name: Jebrael

texts.en:
Jebrael A. is an ambitious man – the hardships in his life didn't stop him from finding a way to take care of his daughter, two sons and wife. Jebrael doesn't have enough money or a degree to start his own shop. He started with a small amount of capitA., buying a small number of gift items and home items to sell door-to-door. Jebrael also sells souvenirs, as Bethlehem is a tourist attraction.

Jebrael now has customers who ask him for certain gift items and home items that he buys and brings to them. He came to FATEN and took out a loan to purchase a large number of items ordered by his customers.

Jebrael appears in the picture above.

loans.use: To purchase gift items to sell

loans.name: Jenneth

texts.en:
Single parenting is hard, all the more when you match it with being a hardworking entrepreneur. Jenneth V., 43, juggles both of these, but is not on the giving up side of the stick. Jenneth finished only high school, but she knows that her entrepreneurial training from CCT* will enable her to succeed. Jenneth is a widow raising three children. They used to live in Sultan Kudarat a few years ago, but now they reside in Tondo, Manila.

Jenneth owns a sari-sari (variety) store which she operates from her house. She has been in this business for two years now, and has managed to gain regular customers from her neighbors and friends. She earns around 9,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month.

To help her grow her business, she has applied for a 13,000 PHP loan. She will use this money to buy more rice for retailing and soft drinks, which are often sought after by people who stay long under the sun. With this, she hopes to increase both her profits and her savings. 

Just like any ordinary sari-sari store owner in the Philippines, Jenneth finds it hard to deal with customers who manage to keep long lists of debts. Nevertheless, she stands firm on her hope that soon she will break through and succeed as an entrepreneur. She dreams of transforming her small store into a mini grocery. Also, just like any loving parent, she desires to see her children graduate from college and have a good future. 

	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: purchase variety store inventory

loans.name: Abigaël Group

texts.fr: Kamwanya M.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Abigaël, âgée de 55 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants.  Son conjoint est un policier, officier de l’ordre public. Kamwanya M.  est vendeuse de Chikwange (aliment approprié et original aux congolais-Kinshasa)  à son domicile.  Elle fait également le commerce de divers pour accroitre ses revenus. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Depuis 1998, elle exerce cette activité traditionnelle. Vers 2007, elle diversifia son activité avec le commerce de divers.  Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ au début de  2010. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  des nouveaux produits (manioc, eau, sachets emballage, braise, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne voir ses enfants qui sont à l’université finir leurs études. La cliente Kamwanya M.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Abigaël est constitué de 37 membres.
texts.en:
Kamwanya M. is an entrepreneure, and president of the Abigaël solidarity group, which is composed of 37 members. She is 55 years old, married, and the mother of three children. Her husband is a police officer. Kamwanya M. sells Chikwange (a typical Kinshasa-Congolese bread dish) from her home. She also sells various other items to increase her income. 

She started her business with her own funds received from her husband, and has been engaged in this traditional activity since 1998. In 2007, she diversified her business by selling a variety of goods. Later, in early 2010, she obtained a $50 loan from the Hekima MFI. 

Kamwanya M. will use the new loan to stock up on merchandise (cassava, water, packaging bags, charcoal, etc.). She also plans to help her children finish their university studies. 

Kamwanya M. wishes to thank the Hekima MFI for helping the less fortunate who do not have access to traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy cassava, water, packaging bags, charcoal, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

He has operated a "nyama choma" (roasted meat) business for the last six months. He sells at the market to his neighbours and passersby. Elijah faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in his business. He hopes to own a butcher shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase kitchen utensils (cooking pots, plates, spoons). He decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen utensils (cooking pots, plates, spoons)

loans.name: Ala

texts.en:
Ala B. is a young married woman from Bethlehem. She runs a store with her husband. They sell all kinds of home accessories, kitchen tools, dining room accessories, etc.

Ala took out a loan form FATEN to purchase a greater variety of home accessories and items to increase her returns and attract more customers. Ala wishes to have a big store one day and to be able to provide small shops with home accessories.

Ala's husband appears in the picture here, as she is a religious woman and not comfortable with having her picture posted on the web.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of home accessories

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
