El socio es el Sr. Marco; el tiene 55 años de edad y es casado  y tiene 4 hijos; el socio se dedica a al negocio de alquilar equipos de sonido para cualquier tipo de compromiso como matrimonios, fiestas de 15años, bautizos entre otros más el socio lleva años en este negocio y se siente feliz ya que mediante este negocio el solventa los gastos de su hogar, siendo esta la única actividad que realiza el socio.  

El socio solicita el préstamo para realizar el mantenimiento de sus equipos de filmación y otra clase de equipos.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Mr. Marco belongs to the SUMAC SONCCO Communal Bank, located in the district, province and department of Cusco.

Marco is 55, married, and has 4 children. He has a business where he rents out sound equipment for every kind of event, such as weddings, 15th birthday parties, and baptisms, among others. He has had this business for several years and is happy because this business covers his household costs. This is his only job.

He is requesting this loan for maintenance for his equipment.

He is happy to have this loan and promises to honour the payments of his quotas.

loans.use: for maintenance for his film equipment and other equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy blue school pants, white school shirts, mens' shoes and jeans

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
El señor Gerardo V. y su esposa la señora Miriam Ivonne Alcaraz, ya han tenido dos créditos con Kiva los cuales sus pagos son puntuales. 
Están nueva mente solicitando un préstamo para poder reparar el techo de su vivienda ya que por las lluvias se ha estado deteriorando. 
Es por eso que están solicitando su cooperación para este crédito ya que no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de realizar la mejora. 
Don Gerardo V. tiene dos ingresos uno es como empleado en una compañía de trasportes, su segundo ingreso es de arbito los fines de semana, estos son los ingresos que tiene para su familia y con una parte de estos ingresos pagara el crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Gerardo V. and his wife Mrs. Miriam Ivonne Alcaraz have received two loans through Kiva, which they paid back on time.  Now they are requesting a new loan to repair the roof of their home which has been damaged due to rainfall.

They appeal to you for your help since they do not have the money necessary to buy the materials nor pay anyone to take care of the repair.

Gerardo has two jobs, one as an employee of a transportation company and the other as a referee on weekends.  These are the only sources of income for the family.  They will use part of this income to pay back the loan.

loans.use: To repair the roof of his home

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal” SUMAC SONCCO ”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Rosa; ella tiene 43 años de edad, casada y tiene 3 hijos; La socia tiene su negocio venta de mochilas y correas, asocia tiene su stand en el centro comercial el paraíso que se encuentra ubicado por el centro de la ciudad, esta es la única actividad que realiza la socia por el momento, la socia es una persona bien alegre optimista y con muchas ganas de seguir adelante por sus hijos.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de más mercadería para su negocio y así poder implementar y tener más variedad de mochilas para escoger. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota
texts.en:
Rosa belongs to the SUMAC SONCCO  Communal Bank, located in the district, province and department of Cusco.

She is 43, married, and has 3 children. She has a business where she sells backpacks and belts. She has a stand in the El Paraiso shopping center, which is located in the city center. This is currently her only job. She is a very optimistic and happy person with a great desire to succeed for the sake of her children.

She is requesting this loan for the purchase of more merchandise for her business in order to stock up and have a greater variety of backpacks for her customers to choose from.

She is happy to have this loan and promises to honour the payments of her quotas.

loans.use: for the purchase of more merchandise for her business in order to stock up and have a greater variety of backpacks.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn D. C. is 37 years old and married with two school-aged children. She is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of income comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods and toothpaste in the local community. She also buys and sells rice by the kilogram. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

Marilyn joined HSPFI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods, junk foods and rice. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Marilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products to sell

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en: Bolormaa is 23 years old and lives with her 2-year-old daughter in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her daughter live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, within her parents' fence. Bolormaa operates a cellphone and cellphone-parts business out of a rented stall in the local trade center. She started her business in 2009 and has made much progress with her business. The success of her business has raised her working capital from 650,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) when she started with five mobiles and other spare parts to a level exceeding 2,000,000 MNT today. She will use this loan to purchase more mobiles and spare parts as well as to increase her product line by selling a variety of souvenir products. Bolormaa is a hardworking and helpful person and is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase cellphones and cellphone parts as well as souvenir products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase cellphones and cellphone parts

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva D. C. is from the village of Langcataon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Eva is married. To make a living, Eva operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Eva has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Eva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and threads. Eva is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Eva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Ma. Gretchen

texts.en:
Ma. Gretchen O. is 32 years old and single. She is from the village of Kiara, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. To make a living, Ma. Gretchen owns and operates a mini-restaurant and retail store. Her main source of income comes primarily from serving a variety of different meals, such as afritada, adobo and bulalo, to customers in the local community. Ma. Gretchen also sells canned goods and beverages in her store. Ma. Gretchen has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

Ma. Gretchen joined HSPFI in 2008 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Gretchen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. She is requesting a loan of 17,000 PHP to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Ma. Gretchen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her businesses.

Her main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling clothing and goods such as caps, blouses, sandals and blankets in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Jose Juan

texts.es:
El señor José Juan M. tiene ya mas once años dedicándose a la reparación de autos, este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia. 
Don José Juan ya ha tenido tres créditos con kiva los cuales ha utilizado para invertir en su taller, esta nuevamente solicitando un préstamo ya que necesita comprar herramientas mas modernas y partes eléctricas para autos, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para invertir en la negocio. 
Es por eso que esta solicitando su cooperación en este préstamo y así tener lo necesario en su negocio, para darle a sus clientes un buen servicio.
texts.en:
Mr. José Juan M. has been repairing automobiles for over eleven years.  This business is the only source of income for his family.  José Juan has already had three loans through Kiva which he has invested in his workshop.  He plans to use this new loan to buy more advanced tools and electric auto repair parts, since he does not have the money to do this himself right now. 

He kindly requests your help so he can obtain what he needs for his business and provide his customers with the best service possible.

loans.use: To buy tools and auto repair parts

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya is a 34-year-old and lives with her 11-year-old son in the Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She and her son live together in a house with a fence. Her son currently attends a local secondary school. Her husband works for the concrete-block producing company during the summer months. 

Enhtuya operates a meat-trading business out of a rented stall at the local trade center in her town. She started her business in 2006 and has since gained much experience. Today, her working capital exceeds 600,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). In addition, she plants and grows a variety of vegetables to sell at the local market for a profit. 

For the future, she plans to increase her working capital for her meat-trading business and enlarge the field where she plants her vegetables in order to increase her vegetable sales. With her business earnings, she was able to afford to buy her own house with fence. 

Enhtuya is a hardworking and modest person and is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve a large amount of meat in order to sell it during the spring months, when prices for such products traditionally rise.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve a large amount of meat

loans.name: Munhdalai

texts.en:
Munhdalai is 32 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent called a "ger". His oldest son attends a local secondary school while his youngest two daughters stay at home with his wife. Munhdalai owns his own car and is a taxi driver in town. 

He started his first business in 2009 with the help of his wife by operating a cafe in a rented space. In 2010, they closed their cafe because his wife gave birth, so he started a taxi business to support his family. Munhdalai is a hardworking, modest and active man who said, "All I wish [is] to raise my children to be good people with high education so that they can live a decent life on their own in the future." He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan in order to make necessary repairs to his taxi and replace parts as well as to buy furniture for his home.

loans.use: To make necessary repairs to his taxi and replace certain parts

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Yon R., age 30, is a construction worker who lives in the province of Kompong Thom. Yon R. earns about 2.50 USD per day. His wife, Eang Thon, is a 33-year-old woman who makes a profit of about 2 USD per day by feeding pigs in the cage behind her house. They have only one child, who is studying in a local school. Yon R. sees that his wife's business is profitable for the family. Thus, he would like to request a loan to support his wife in buying more small pigs to raise and sell.

loans.use: To buy more small pigs to raise and sell

loans.name: Jeckie

texts.en:
Jeckie T. is from the village of Kipaducan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old, married and has 2 children in school. To make a living, Jeckie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as ice buko salad and ice cream salad in the local community. Jeckie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jeckie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jeckie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as working capital and to purchase additional ingredients. Jeckie is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale such as creams and milk. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jeckie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue this will generate to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products such as creams and milk for sale

loans.name: Wena

texts.en:
Wena is a married woman who lives in Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: ice cream making and Trisikad (or pedicab) operator businesses. Her husband Gino T., who is 34 years old, works as a Brgy. Police officer and Trisikad driver to earn a living. They have no children. 

Wena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Wena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 18,000, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she can improve her business, repair her house and have savings in the future. Wena is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'Honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to grow her business

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg, 29, lives with her husband in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in her parents' fence. Her husband operates a taxi service using his own motorcycle. Narantsetseg operates a clothing retail business from a stall at a local clothing market. She started her business in 2004 selling only socks, underwear and children's clothing items. As her sales was not very good, she decided to change her product line by selling a variety of jeans to her customers. She is a very open-minded and sociable woman. For the future, she plans to expand her business. Narantsetseg is requesting a loan of 1,300,000 MNT to purchase more winter clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothing items.

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en:
Constancia is a widow living in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. She has six children between 40 and 50 years old. Constancia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Constancia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 5,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 3,500 PHP, raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save for her future business and family needs. Constancia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Vivencia

texts.en: Vivencia P. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Vivencia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Vivencia buys and raises pigs for sale. Vivencia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Vivencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Vivencia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Vivencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra S. is from the village of Kimanait, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 26 years-old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Zandra owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, detergents, junk food and toothpaste in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Zandra joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Zandra is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and junk food. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny J. is an Industrious and business-minded young mother. She is 26 years-old from Villar, Sibalom, Antique Philippines. She is living with her partner in life, Romel Samillano, and they are blessed with one child (John Emmanuel).

While their child is still young, she wanted to earn more in order to have savings for the education of their children.

Despite some difficulties she never gives up especially in fulfilling her responsibilities as a mother and as a member of Kiva partner ASHI. She has performed well because she wanted to use a house repair loan in order to renovate their house so that it is comfortable for them.

At present, she is asking for a new loan in the amount of  PHP 9,000.00 which she plans to use to provide additional capital for her pig raising business.

She hopes that someday  through the help of ASHI and its field partners, she will be able to take a larger loan so that they will have more income in order to sustain their needs. She wants to give a bright future for her child.

loans.use: Hog fattening

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy S. is 55 years old. She has a wooden house and a grocery shop, selling many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and gasoline. Tuy S. sells her inventory to people passing by and to her neighbors. She has been running a grocery store for over ten years, and she earns an average of 2.50 USD a day. To provide their family with financial stability, her husband drives a motor-taxi. This couple has three children who live at home. S. will be using the loan she requested to purchase cooking ingredients, fish paste, and other necessary items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cooking ingredients, fish paste, and other necessary items to sell

loans.name: Heligena

texts.en:
Heligena C. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 38 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Heligena owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general services such as repainting cars and jeeps for local community members. Her husband is working in their vulcanizing shops. Heligena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Heligena joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Heligena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Heligena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Heligena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business: a general store  .Her husband, Juanito, who is 62 years-old, works as a Driver to earn his living.  They have five children who are 25 to 32 years old. Three of their children have their own families.

Teresita joined Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teresita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, and she plans to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of her business.

Teresita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 42 year-old widowed mother who lives with her two children, ages 17 and 13, in the S. district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house with a fence. Her oldest daughter attends a construction college while her youngest son attends a secondary school. 

Her husband passed away and she supports her two children by operating a mobile meal selling business. She cooks a variety of meals and foods in a rented space and delivers these hot meals to the markets and office buildings according to her customers' orders. She started her business in 2007 and has since built a stable operation. She has hired an additional worker for her cafe. 

Purevsuren says, "all I want to do is provide a higher education for my two children." For the future, she plans to open her own cafe. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to add to her working capital and to purchase and preserve a large amount of meat for her meal making business.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve a large amount of meat.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia L. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, detergents, snack foods and toothpaste in her community. She is 53 years old, married and has seven grown-up children. She is from the village of Miaray, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. Lilia has been in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Lilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods and canned goods. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines.
